instruction: It's written in the stars, you know? It's part of my genetic code. Some people are destined to be losers and victims.
output: I think by coming here, you show that you're willing to overcome what you perceive as your destiny. You want to stop being a victim, you want to put a stop to your self-destructive behaviors.

instruction: I think it's hopeless. I'm thirty now. I'm all washed up.
output: Happy birthday. I hardly think your life is over at 30.

instruction: I'm a fossil. I'm old and decrepit. An old geezer. I hate being old. Let's talk about something else.
output: How are things at home?

instruction: Charlotte and Rob are not on good terms. They took me out for my birthday, and it went badly. They haven't talked much to each other since.
output: What happened?

instruction: Charlotte wanted to try this new Japanese restaurant. She read about it in the pink section of the Chronicle and heard it was a trendy new eatery. Of course, there was a long line; we waited nearly an hour before we got a table. When we finally sat down, we were crammed in a tiny space. And Charlotte's not exactly petite. Then Rob knocked over his cup of tea, and Charlotte started snapping at him. She was in a really foul mood and was argumentative and irritable.
output: Hmm.

instruction: And since I'm a half-Jap, she wanted me to impress the waitress by ordering in Japanese. The waitress looked Americanized enough to me. I told Charlotte I was a little rusty, and she launched into a tirade--how valuable knowing a foreign language could be, how I could broaden my career opportunities and even work overseas, and blah blah blah. I was relieved when the food came, so Charlotte could stuff her face and leave me alone. You know how to eat sushi, don't you?
output: Sure.

instruction: I've never seen San Franciscans so clumsy with Japanese food. Charlotte picked up pieces of futomaki with her fingers, for Christ sake! And she took pickled ginger and placed it on top of the futomaki--like she was putting cheese on a cracker--and then slopped soy sauce all over it and ate it that way! She couldn't stuff that whole mess into her gaping maw, so she tried to eat it in bites and got rice all over the table. It was disgusting.
output: Hmm. I think you might be over reacting a bit to her...

instruction: When the miso soup came, Charlotte asked for a spoon. A spoon! She pantomimed spooning soup in to her mouth for the waitress, while saying loudly, "You know, spoon!" That was pretty condescending; the waitress' English was just fine. Charlotte must subscribe to the belief that Asians can understand English only if it is spoken loudly and slowly and with appropriate hand gestures. I don't know why it bothered me so much. I was embarrassed, I guess.
output: I see.

instruction: Anyway, Charlotte nagged and complained throughout dinner. She sent back her food twice--she's a picky eater. And she complained all the way home. When we got home, I went to my room, while she started on Rob. He's usually pretty quiet, but after a while, he started yelling back. I couldn't hear much, but I heard my name come up a few times. I heard a door slam when Charlotte left.
output: Hmm.

instruction: Rob didn't mention it the next day. He gave me a new coat, though. He said it was from him and Charlotte for my birthday. It was really nice--a London Fog. I haven't had a new coat in years.
output: How are you and Rob getting along?

instruction: We're both painfully shy, antisocial, and neurotic--we get along fine.
output: I see. You've talked about some difficult subjects today. How do you feel now?

instruction: I'm all right. I feel a little weird about it. It still bothers me, kind of...
output: What bothers you?

instruction: That you know so much. That you might tell the people that I work with about my sordid past.
output: You know that won't happen

instruction: Yeah, well...I'm a little paranoid.
output: I'm glad that you were willing to take this step, Sharon. It shows that you're making progress.

instruction: Yeah, but I'm still a loser--a thirty-year-old loser.
output: I don't agree with your self-assessment. In my professional opinion, it's a little too soon to diagnose yourself as a "loser," even if you've reached the ripe old age of thirty. However, I understand that there are issues you want to work on--that's what brought you to therapy. Change doesn't take place immediately. Growth is a gradual process.

instruction: Okay, Doctor. See you next week.
output: Goodbye, Sharon.

instruction: Not so good. My ferret died.
output: Oh, I'm very sorry. How did it happen?

instruction: I used to let Harriet run around in the garage while I did laundry. Charlotte came by unexpectedly. She and Rob had a fight last week, so they haven't been speaking. She used her garage-door opener to get into the house and left the door open. I guess Harriet must have gotten out or maybe the dog came in. I was in the house when it happened. The neighbor's dog got hold of Harriet somehow. When I talked to them later, they said they found the remains of some small animal in their yard. I was too upset to look. I guess its my fault really, though I was pretty upset with Charlotte.
output: It sounds like an accident. Why do you blame yourself?

instruction: If I'd been out there, this wouldn't have happened. A part of me resents Charlotte for coming and going as she pleases. But that doesn't make sense--it's her house. She didn't even seem to care when I told her what happened. Charlotte only came by to borrow the bread-maker. I was pretty hysterical--I was sobbing and ranting. I think she just wanted to get away from me.
output: Hmm. It's hard to lose...

instruction: I feel like a bad parent. I'm a bad pet owner. I think someone like me doesn't deserve to live. I'm a total failure.
output: Sharon, you're being very hard on yourself.

instruction: My life is like some cruel joke by a malevolent deity. I think if there is a god, he wouldn't be a big muscular guy with a white beard throwing lightning bolts--like Zeus or the god of the Old Testament. God would definitely be a woman, most likely a prepubescent girl--spoiled and self-absorbed--who enjoys petty cruelties.
output: Hmm.

instruction: This would explain a lot of inconsistencies.
output: You sound very depressed.

instruction: Yeah, what else is new? And it doesn't help that I hate my job. And I've been having...uh, female trouble.
output: What do you mean by that?

instruction: Well, I don't want to gross you out with the lurid details. I'd like to save that for my gynecologist. I've been bleeding continuously for a little over two weeks. At first, it was just an irregular menstrual period--I've had those before--but the bleeding won't stop. And I've also been getting these dizzy spells--all of a sudden, I get weak and nauseous. Sometimes, I get these splitting, blinding headaches. Maybe it's early menopause.
output: Is there any chance you could be pregnant?

instruction: No, you have to have sex to get pregnant.
output: Have you made an appointment with your OB/GYN?

instruction: I keep hoping it would go away.
output: I think it would be a good idea for you to see your doctor right away, just to rule out something serious.

instruction: I don't really care if it is. Maybe I have an ovarian cancer. That's how my grandmother died. My mother had to have a hysterectomy. It must run in the family.
output: Then you should definitely see a doctor as soon as possible.  This is not something you just want to wait on.

instruction: I don't really care if I die. I'm not motivated enough to actually buy a gun, or patient enough to hoard medication. I'm not really suicidal. But it would be okay if I were to be hit by a speeding bus, or a large hailstone were to drop on my head.
output: I see.

instruction: Cancer really wouldn't be such a bad way to go. It's kind of romantic and tragic.
output: Death by cancer is slow and painful--hardly the stuff of lyric poetry.

instruction: Would you miss me if I were dead?
output: Yes.  Sharon, I don't want any of my patients to die. I'm very concerned for your welfare. I'm concerned that your depression will lead you to inaction with regard to this matter, and I think that's highly self-destructive.  Please see your doctor.

instruction: Don't cancer patients get really thin? Just think, I could fit into my jeans again.
output: That's not funny, Sharon.

instruction: What if I have AIDS? That would be even worse. It's considered quite chic in San Francisco to have AIDS. I could get free food and t-shirts and everything.
output: Is there a chance that you might be HIV-positive?

instruction: I don't know. I was tested a few years ago--when I was sleeping around a lot--and I was negative.
output: Perhaps it would be a good idea to get tested again, and not only for HIV.

instruction: I want to let nature take its course.
output: Why do you feel this way?

instruction: I've already told you--I'm a miserable person. I'm a mishap, a system error. I can't even take care of a fucking ferret. What a loser!
output: I think some of your feelings of depression might be attributed to your physical condition, which is why it is important that you get immediate medical attention.

instruction: Oh, jeez...
output: Sharon? Sharon, what's the matter?

instruction: I'm dizzy. I don't feel so good.
output: Do you need to lie down?

instruction: I just feel weak...
output: Put on your coat. I'm going to take you to the Emergency Room.

instruction: No! No, I just need to go home. I'll make a doctor's appointment for tomorrow, I promise. Please, I just want to go home. I can't handle waiting four hours in E.R. right now. I'll go home and lie down, and I'll call an OB/GYN tomorrow, okay?
output: All right, Sharon. Do you feel well enough to drive home?

instruction: I took the bus.
output: Let me call you a cab.

instruction: That's okay, I can't afford...
output: Sharon?

instruction: Oh, no. Oh my god, I'm so sorry.
output: That's all right, Sharon. Here, use the wastebasket.

instruction: I'll clean this up...
output: It's all right. The janitor will take care of it. I'll call you a cab. Do you need a glass of water?

instruction: No, I'm okay. Thanks, Doctor Balis.  If you don't mind, I'll wait for it downstairs--I need some fresh air.
output: Sure.  Please call me and let me know what's wrong with you.  Okay?

instruction: Not too bad, I guess, considering.
output: Did you have the laparoscopy as scheduled?

instruction: Yeah. I went through with it. I'm glad it's over. I have a follow up appointment in two weeks.
output: That's good. Are you still having pain?

instruction: Some. I'm still pissed that they wouldn't give me any cool drugs. Laparoscopy is considered a major surgery. Why couldn't they have given me a prescription for pain killers?
output: You seem very eager to obtain a prescription.

instruction: You would too if you had your nads ripped off.
output: Hmm.

instruction: Okay, maybe that's a little extreme. I've been feeling really rotten lately. Between work, my female trouble, and the banality and emptiness of my existence...well, I'm not exactly doing cartwheels.
output: You've had a rash of stressful situations lately.

instruction: Bad things happen to bad people.
output: Hmm. Explain what you mean by that.

instruction: I see it as karmic retribution.
output: Retribution for what?

instruction: I don't know. The sins I committed in my past life. There must be some reason why I am what I am.
output: Last week, you mentioned that you would welcome an early death. Have you had any thoughts about taking you're own life again?

instruction: I distinctly remember saying that I was too lazy and passive to actually do anything. So you can't say I'm a suicide risk and lock me up forever in a rubber room, Doctor.
output: Given your history, I would be remiss in my duties as a therapist if I did not ask you that question. You need to be honest with yourself, Sharon. Do you feel you're at risk?

instruction: No. I really don't. I don't have the energy to actually carry it out. I get some comfort by thinking about it, though. Like it's always there for me.
output: Hmm. How do you feel now compared to how you felt before your attempt last year?

instruction: Last year, I felt frantic and desperate. Now, I just feel numb, like I don't really care about anything. I'm not really depressed, though I'm so used to feeling down that I can't really tell any more.
output: About a month ago, you gave me a copy of a poem delineating various suicide methods. If you were to formulate a plan to take your own life, what would it be?

instruction: Jeez, who are you, Kenneth Starr? I'm starting to feel like I'm being interrogated in front of the Grand Jury. You're starting to sound like the Special Prosecutor.
output: I'm just concerned about you. You've been expressing feelings like those of people who are deeply depressed and even suicidal.

instruction: I'm lazy and suicidal.
output: I see.

instruction: There aren't any easy methods. Remember that book, "Final Exit?" It detailed suicide methods for elderly people who were seriously ill. It stirred up all this controversy; the media made it seem like everyone who read that book would try to kill themselves. What's funny is that the methods detailed in "Final Exit" aren't exactly user friendly; you have to have access to prescription drugs and the patience to hoard them. That's out of reach for an ordinary person like me. And that was supposed to be the point of the poem I gave you--it's just easier to let life take its course.
output: That can be a very self-destructive point of view.

instruction: Well, I'm not going to kill myself, Doctor.
output: I'm relieved to hear that.

instruction: Do you believe in destiny?
output: Destiny? Why do you ask?

instruction: It seems that some people are destined for greatness, like Stephen Hawking or John F. Kennedy. Or Monica Lewinsky.
output: Hmm.

instruction: I guess Monica was destined more for notoriety.
output: I see your point.

instruction: When I was watching all the tabloid coverage of the presidential sex scandal, it seemed that Monica Lewinsky was programmed to be what she was. Her mother was a social climber, her parents went through a bad divorce, her father was critical and distant. You know that saying, "You are the sum total of your experiences?" Maybe I was destined to fail so that I could be the bad example. I was placed here so overbearing maternal types could point at me and say, "Don't be like her."
output: That's a rather negative view of yourself.

instruction: I feel so weary of life. I don't even want to get up in the morning. I hate my job, my pet ferret is dead, I have no reason to live.
output: You mentioned earlier that you loathe working for SII.

instruction: I've been demoted. When I came back after being out for the surgery, my boss told me to report to Human Resources. I'm doing clerical work--filing and sorting stuff. Ordinarily, I'd be angry and frustrated because I worked so hard in that department. But now, I'm just don't care any more. I don't care about the demotion from secretary to clerk, about the cut in pay, about the fact that I do grunt work for this monstrously obese woman who eats M&M's all day. She makes me think of a whale engulfing swarms of multi-colored plankton.
output: Hmm.

instruction: I'm beginning to think my boss planned this just to torment me. He has me working for the most repulsive person at SII. I always knew he had it in for me. Maybe this is a way of getting me to quit.
output: I think you might be reading too much into this.

instruction: You can never be too paranoid, you know? Especially when you're working for a corporation.
output: I see.

instruction: Maybe it's the corporate environment that's getting to me. I wish I could get paid for watching television. Maybe I could get disability? I'd have to be certifiably nuts first. Being physically healthy can contribute to your overall sense of well being. The other problem with drug use is that they affect the dopamine levels in your brain. output: Sharon, I'd like you to stay here until you feel you're on the road to overcoming your addiction. You haven't used any drugs for a week, and that's very good. But you're not completely recovered yet.

instruction: I'm never going to be completely recovered. Isn't that what they teach you in those insipid twelve step programs? Addicts are addicts for life. I'm always going to have the same addictive personality. Are you planning on keeping me locked up for life?
output: You have a very serious and long-term history of drug use.You've been abusing some very addictive substances. I'm glad you are willing to give this a try. But it's not time to stop yet. You'll benefit from this program the most by remaining here for a while.

instruction: Shit.
output: Have you had any visitors?

instruction: Yeah, I called Rob and he came to see me. He bought me some warm clothes. Why is it so fucking cold in here?
output: Your body's vulnerable. You might be particularly sensitive to cold right now.

instruction: This is like some new-age dungeon. I hate being confined. I hate being locked up like this. Just look at the people here. Have you ever seen so many miserable people in one place in your life? I can't even get a decent cup of coffee.
output: I'm surprised.  I thought coffee was the one drug they pushed here.

instruction: No, they save the coffee for the alcoholics. All we get is herbal tea that tastes like horse piss. Not even a diet Pepsi--it's endless apple juice.
output: Have you participated in any of the group sessions? You'll make greater progress if you take an active role in your recovery.

instruction: Look, Doctor, I don't want to sit with a group of whiners and spill my heart out about my unhappy childhood and all that other crap. And I would have to hug some blubbering idiot. I hate hugging people. It's a plague. It's the scourge of the late 20th century.  Do you know Leo Buscaglia?
output: Hmm.

instruction: Look, I knitted a fucking potholder. That's something, isn't it?
output: It's a good idea to keep your hands busy.

instruction: So I won't claw my eyes out, or attack the other inmates, or try to find a means of escape?
output: You're quite angry.

instruction: You said I'd only be here a week. Why would you lie to me like that?
output: The purpose in your coming here was to get off drugs. Judging by your demeanor...

instruction: My demeanor? What the fuck is wrong with my demeanor?
output: You're still in drug withdrawal. I talked to the staff here, and we all think it would be best for you to stay a bit longer.

instruction: "A bit longer?" You're being deliberately vague. I don't like the idea that you were all talking about me behind my back, plotting against me. You're planning to keep me here forever, aren't you?
output: No, Sharon. No one is trying to keep you here indefinitely. I talked to the other staff members to evaluate your progress. It's fairly routine.

instruction: Why didn't you just ask me? I would have told you I was doing fine.
output: You're not in a postion to be able to make objective judgements.

instruction: So now you're accusing me of lying.
output: Addicts are very poor judges of their abilities to control their addiction. I need objective data. You were able to stay off drugs for a week, and considering the extent of your substance abuse, that's quite remarkable. But if I approve your release now, there's a good chance that you'll go back to using drugs again. I want you to be committed to staying off drugs.

instruction: Okay, I'm committed.
output: Then stay here for another week.

instruction: Fuck, no!
output: Just stay this weekend then. Stay until Monday.

instruction: This is all a big lie. You're not going to let me out on Monday.
output: On Monday, we'll reevaluate you and see if you're ready to leave.

instruction: I'm ready to leave now!
output: If you complete this program successfully, I'll be able to reinstate you at SII.

instruction: I don't want to go back to SII.
output: You don't want to have a job to go back to?

instruction: I don't want to go back to SII.
output: Do you plan to work?

instruction: I don't know. I thought maybe I could collect disability.
output: You're hardly disabled.

instruction: According to law, people who have addictions are disabled. I could get social security.
output: Even if you were able to get it, it's not very much money. In fact, it's only $650 a month. You'd make much more working. Working a regular job would also give your life structure, and you would have something to occupy your time. I recommend that you return to SII, if possible, at least for a short time. If you are truly unhappy there, you can look for other employment opportunities once you get settled in.

instruction: Jeez, what a pain in the ass. I should never have agreed to come here.
output: Addiction and other self-destructive behaviors have serious long-term consequences. It's unrealistic for you to expect that you can stop abusing substances like heroin and methamphetamine overnight. Drug use took a toll on you physically and psychologically. You need to give yourself more time.

instruction: I just don't think it's necessary to have me incarcerated.
output: Stay here for the weekend, Sharon. I'll talk to the staff psychiatrist on Monday and see about your release.

instruction: The head shrink here is a total bonehead, you know. He's so smarmy and unctuous; it's all I can do not to spit in his face when he asks, "And how does that make you feel?"
output: Regardless , I think that...

instruction: I know, I know.  You want me to get with the program.
output: Well, in a manner of speaking, yes.

instruction: Are you sure you're not doing this to get another potholder?
output: I think one will suffice.

instruction: I'll string together a set of love beads, then, in the ugliest fluorescent colors I can find. I'll be terribly hurt if you don't wear them.
output: Continuing with the crafts is a good idea. Maybe you could make something for Rob?

instruction: I was thinking of knitting a matching sweater and hat set for his cat.
output: It's good to have a creative outlet.

instruction: This compulsive knitting may be symptomatic of a deeper underlying disorder, exacerbated by prolonged confinement.
output: Just hang in there, Sharon.

instruction: Okay. Thanks for coming to visit.
output: I'll see you in a few days.  Goodbye, Sharon.

instruction: Hi. I didn't think you'd come here again. You must be a glutton for punishment.
output: I wanted to check on your progress. You seem to be in better spirits.

instruction: They put me on clonidine. I didn't know that they gave drugs to recovering addicts.
output: Hmm.

instruction: My compulsive knitting has abated. I was hoping to churn out several pairs of socks, maybe even argyles for a real challenge, but now all I want to do is watch insipid shows on the television. I can't believe the mind-numbing drivel that's on daytime TV. And what's worse is that I'm addicted to it.
output: Hmm.

instruction: It's interesting to watch bad television with deeply disturbed people--I just watch their reactions. It's kind of like watching second-run movies at a double-feature theater in a bad part of town where the homeless hang out.
output: Have you participated in any of the group sessions?

instruction: Yes, Doctor, I have.
output: Good. Do you think you've gained anything from them?

instruction: I'm an extremely self-absorbed person, so I always think that what I have to say is far more interesting than anyone else's comments. And being arrogant and selfish, not to mention painfully inarticulate, I refrain from commenting.
output: Hmm.

instruction: So group therapy has had mixed results. But I am attending the sessions.
output: I'd like you to continue going to the group meetings. It might be more helpful that you realize.

instruction: The food here really sucks.
output: Institutional cuisine often leaves much to be desired. You won't have to endure it much longer.

instruction: Do you mean I'm getting out soon?
output: Your two-week stay is almost up.

instruction: You better not be teasing me about this.
output: I've always tried to be honest with you, Sharon.

instruction: It seems like I've been here an eternity. It feels more like two months, not two weeks.
output: Do you think it's been beneficial for you to be here?

instruction: Yes, Doctor. I feel like a new and improved person. Thank you so much for this life-changing opportunity to better myself.
output: For some reason, I doubt your sincerity.

instruction: I have to be sincere, too?
output: Just be honest with me, Sharon. It won't affect your release date.

instruction: I'm inclined not to believe that. But I guess I do feel better now. It's a relief not to have the burden of drug addiction, though I do miss it.
output: What do you miss?

instruction: I miss driving with my headphones on, blasted out of my mind. I was listening to the NPR radio show, "Fresh Air," KQED-FM. Peter Coyote was being interviewed, and he discussed his drug use, which included heroin. He said that it was the ritual he enjoyed most: scoring drugs, cooking them, loading up the syringe, tying up his arm to get the vein bulging, putting the needle in. It made me think of how many times I had done that, usually on the floor of a dirty bathroom. It was like I could steal away from the rest of the world into my own.
output: You actually enjoyed the act of injecting yourself with drugs?

instruction: Yes, I did.
output: That seems to be the unpleasant part of drug use.

instruction: Yeah, I guess to a non-user it would seem that way.
output: And you drove while under the influence? Frequently?

instruction: Yeah, I really liked driving when I was high. I got lost a lot, though.
output: Hmm. Did you feel a craving for drugs after you heard that interview?

instruction: Yeah. Well, the clonidine seems to help, but I still miss them. I wish I hadn't heard the interview. That was the problem with twelve-step programs for me. In those meetings, you have to listen to people tell "glory day" stories of their drug use. There's this atmosphere of one-upmanship going on--each person tries to tell a more fantastic story, a more extreme tale of self-destruction. And rather than giving me an aversion to drug use, these meetings made me want to go out and get high again.
output: I see. So you have some experience with twelve-step programs?

instruction: I don't think they helped.
output: I see. Has Rob been in to see you?

instruction: Yeah. I kind of wish he hadn't.
output: Why is that?

instruction: I don't know. I feel guilty when I see him, for some reason. I was hoping not to get too many visitors. Do you know who else came to see me? That woman I work with--the big one, who eats all those M&M's.
output: Really?

instruction: I wonder how she knew I was here? I didn't tell anyone from work. I hope you didn't tell the human resources person at SII.
output: No, Sharon. All information relating to your stay here is confidential.

instruction: I wonder how she found out? She really is annoying. I hate perky people, especially grossly obese perky people. I've nicknamed her "Godzilla." She did bring me a box of candy, though, which was kind of nice, I must admit.
output: I'm sure people at work are concerned about you.

instruction: They never exhibited any concern for me before. What do they know about this?
output: Nothing, as far as I know. Nothing, unless you've told them.

instruction: I haven't talked to anyone about this, except Rob. It's really bugging me! How did Godzilla find out?
output: Don't obsess about it, Sharon. She was just expressing her concern.

instruction: She's getting grist for the gossip mill, no doubt.
output: Are you looking forward to going back to SII?

instruction: No. Are you kidding? I couldn't stand going back there without being stoned.
output: I suggest you try it, at least for the short term. It would be good for you to have some stability in your life. It's not a good idea to make drastic changes when you're this vulnerable. Recovery can be a very delicate period.

instruction: Yeah.
output: You should be released tomorrow; do you have someone to take you home?

instruction: I can take myself home.
output: Why not have Rob pick you up? I'm sure he won't mind.

instruction: He'll drag me to some restaurant and force me to eat. Though at this point, I wouldn't mind a decent meal.
output: Give him a call. I don't want you going home alone.

instruction: Don't trust me, huh?
output: It's generally recommended that a patient leaving any sort of facility be escorted home. You might not be in the best condition to drive.

instruction: And I'll be working at SII starting next week?
output: Yes, if you feel ready.

instruction: I'm as ready as I'll ever be.
output: Good. I'll be seeing you in my office next week, at our regular time.

instruction: All right. Thanks, Doctor Balis.
output: You're welcome. Goodbye, Sharon.

instruction: Hi. I almost didn't come today. I was afraid you'd strong-arm me into going back to another nut house.
output: I assume you're referring to California Pacific's substance abuse treatment center.

instruction: Yes.
output: As long as you're able to stay off drugs, there's no reason for you to go back. I'd like you to continue working on your recovery. Were you able to attend the substance abuse group that the hospital referred you to?

instruction: I went to the Rational Recovery group earlier this week. Their approach is completely different from, say, Narcotics Anonymous. A therapist leads the group discussion, instead of a reformed drunk or druggie. I didn't have to hold hands or say that asinine serenity prayer, either. I always hated that; it was so trite.
output: I understand that some people involved in Rational Recovery left traditional twelve-step programs because of philosophical differences with the "higher power" concept. Do you consider yourself an atheist or agnostic?

instruction: I consider myself extremely intolerant of people who follow pop-psychology and that mushy-headed new-age jargon they all speak. I have to admit that I like Rational Recovery's straightforward, no-nonsense approach. The people there seemed real, not like the insufferably sanctimonious brainwashed zombies you see at AA meetings, who speak almost entirely in twelve-step clichés like that Stuart Smalley character from Saturday Night Live.
output: Good. I'd like you to attend these sessions every week.

instruction: What? I have to go back there again?
output: Recovery from substance abuse is a continual process, and many former addicts find it helpful to have support, particularly in the beginning.

instruction: What's the difference between a drunk and an alcoholic?
output: What?

instruction: A drunk doesn't have to go to those stupid meetings. That's an old joke. I couldn't resist.
output: I'd like you to return to the Rational Recovery group at least one more time.

instruction: Okay, okay, I'll go. This is an effective form of aversion therapy, punishing drug use with recovery group meetings.
output: It's not so bad, Sharon, admit it. And consider the alternative.

instruction: I hate it when you're right.
output: How are things at home?

instruction: Okay, I guess.
output: How is your relationship with Rob?

instruction: Relationship? I never really thought of it that way. I guess we do have a relationship, of sorts.
output: How have you two been getting along?

instruction: "You two?" How romantic. You make it sound like we're a couple. Boyfriend-girlfriend, significant other, whatever you want to call it.
output: How do you characterize your relationship with Rob?

instruction: He's the guy I fuck because I can't come up with the rent. I don't dislike him, though. We get along pretty well. I think we get along so well because we don't see each other much. Though sometimes, I think I'm making a big mistake.
output: How so?

instruction: I've done something so fundamentally wrong, something universally regarded as immoral.
output: Do you mean having an affair with a married man?

instruction: Yes. Though I don't think of him as married really. He's been separated for a long time.
output: Have you had any interaction with his wife?

instruction: No, thank God. Rob mentioned wanting to file divorce papers, but I don't think he means it. I don't think he'll ever leave Charlotte, at least not in the legal sense.
output: Hmm. Do you enjoy spending time with Rob?

instruction: I have mixed feelings about him. I've always thought that having an affair like this--with someone who is married--would be torrid and passionate. But there's no passion at all, just perfunctory sex and endless household chores. He's getting a really good deal, I think. I wonder how much it would cost him to hire a maid he could fuck? That's what all men want, you know.
output: Hmm.

instruction: And sometimes...well, this is a terrible thing to say.
output: You may always speak freely here.

instruction: I have a hard time not making value judgments based on appearance. And that's not very fair, because of what I look like. I'm not what anyone would call a great beauty.
output: You don't find Rob physically attractive?

instruction: Rob really likes hippopotamuses. What is the plural of hippopotamus? It can't be hippopotami, can it?
output: I'm not sure.

instruction: He has a hippopotamus calendar on the wall in his bedroom. They are really repulsive, grotesque animals. Did you know that the social status of a hippo is determined by how far he can spray his dung? They spray their feces by wiggling their tails around, and the one who can spray the most and the farthest is held in high esteem by the other hippos.
output: I think you've been watching too much Discovery Channel. But we're getting off the subject.

instruction: I thought the subject was hippos.
output: Very funny. We were discussing your feelings about Rob.

instruction: Hippos are much more interesting.
output: Are you dissatisfied with Rob as a partner because he likes hippos?

instruction: That seems like a good reason, doesn't it? I sense Rob's sense of kinship with large, dirty, smelly, mud-wallowing mammals is related to their common physical traits.
output: Such as?

instruction: Immense girth and poor hygiene.
output: Are you sure you're not exaggerating a bit?

instruction: He's at a physical extreme. If it weren't so extreme, I wouldn't be bothered by it. But his stomach is so distended that his bellybutton is stretched out like a pregnant woman's. It's hard to have sex because of it. When he gets on top, I can't breathe.
output: You might try different positions.

instruction: That's too disgusting to even consider.
output: Hmm.

instruction: And anyway, all these new doors are opened when you have sex with someone. And it's really weird having sex when you're not stoned.
output: Have you spoken to Rob about this?

instruction: No, I don't want to hurt his feelings.
output: There are ways you can broach the subject and still be tactful.

instruction: Yeah, right. "Hey, fat ass, you stink. And you're a lousy lay, too."
output: I'm sure if you work on it, you can find something less caustic than that.

instruction: I can't complain. He's giving me a place to stay.
output: Hmm.

instruction: I met this very attractive man at the substance abuse group. We were walking into the building at the same time, and he asked me where the meeting was being held. It made me very uncomfortable. I stammered and felt my face get hot. I rode with him in the elevator--I couldn't think of an excuse to get away. He made small talk, and I felt so awkward. If I was more self confident, maybe I would have flirted or at least been more forthcoming. But all I could do was give monosyllabic answers like a brain-damaged teenager.
output: I see.

instruction: Pretty silly, isn't it? I'm thirty years old, and I don't have the social graces to handle even the simplest of human interactions.
output: Were you attracted to him?

instruction: I'm a little embarrassed to admit it, but yes. I haven't really noticed people around me, probably because I've been in a drug-induced daze for the past few months.
output: Most of us have little control over whom we find physically attractive. The feelings of nervousness or uneasiness you described are completely normal. It's also normal for people to be somewhat "lookist" if you will. Few people can avoid being swayed by appearances. Have you given any thought to dating?

instruction: Well, no. Maybe in theory, but not in practice. The thought of social interaction of any kind is almost enough to make me break out in hives. It's all too intimidating. And I don't think Rob would like it.
output: I see.

instruction: I feel that I owe Rob a lot for taking me in. But at the same time, I resent him because there's so much about our relationship--or whatever you want to call it--that isn't very satisfying. Did you see the movie, "Wild Man Blues?"
output: The documentary about Woody Allen? No, I haven't seen it yet.

instruction: There's a scene where Woody Allen refers to Soon-Yi as a "kid who ate out of garbage cans." I found that remark disturbing, especially since he said it in an offhanded way. It seems to me that he'll always see her as a street urchin, a charity case, no matter how old she is or what she accomplishes. He seems to be implying that she is somehow beneath him, a substandard woman or something. He isn't capable of seeing her as an equal or a partner. And I think Rob sees me the same way.
output: What makes you think that?

instruction: Because of the circumstances that brought us together. If it weren't for his good graces, I'd probably be living in my car or in some squalid residential hotel in the Tenderloin. I'm indebted to Rob, and I can't see anyone else, not that I would want to or could. I'm sure the incredibly good-looking guy I met at the group would never be interested in someone like me. But I keep thinking: if Rob isn't in the picture, maybe it can happen. I'm not really single, but not really attached in any formal, meaningful way. I'm caught in a strange sort of limbo.
output: Hmm.

instruction: I can't even talk to anyone about it. I would never mention it to women at work. Some of them are married, and I don't want to be labeled a home wrecker.
output: I can understand your desire to want to keep your private life to yourself, but people aren't always judgmental.

instruction: Yeah, I've heard rumors about some of the people at SII and...I guess my situation wouldn't shock them. But women can be extremely critical of other women.
output: What's it like to be back at work?

instruction: Boring. Dull. Tedious. I asked Godzilla how she knew about the detox. She said she "heard it from someone in the office," but I don't believe that. She's in management, maybe she has access to confidential personnel files.
output: I wouldn't worry about it.

instruction: She's asking me all these questions. I think she's up to something.
output: She might just be expressing interest in you out of concern.

instruction: Yeah, well...
output: We're almost out of time.

instruction: Wow, I didn't realize I've been rambling on so long.
output: We've covered a lot of ground in this session. How does it feel to be back?

instruction: I hate that "how does it feel" question. Okay, I guess.
output: All right, Sharon, I'll see you next week.

instruction: Thanks, Doctor Balis.
output: Goodbye.

instruction: I broke several bones in my foot. I'm on crutches for at least a month, that's what the doctor said.
output: How did this happen?

instruction: Charlotte backed her car over my foot.
output: She did what?

instruction: I was in so much shock, the pain didn't even register until later. Charlotte didn't see me, and I didn't get out of the way fast enough. I don't think it was deliberate, even though she does have some animosity towards me.
output: What makes you say that?

instruction: She holds me responsible for breaking up her marriage, but Rob says it was broken to begin with--it had been for several years. I was pretty pissed off at both of them, but I've calmed down since then.
output: You're not angry anymore?

instruction: I wish I could say that. Actually, I think all the painkillers I've been taking have rendered me "comfortably numb" like the Pink Floyd song.
output: What painkillers are you taking?

instruction: Charlotte was leaving in a hurry--she and Rob had been arguing again--she backed out without looking. I didn't realize she was backing up; then I heard my bones crack. All I could think of was that I needed to get to the emergency room. Charlotte and Rob were screaming at each other when it happened. Rob said that if I waited a few minutes for him to take care of Charlotte, he'd drive me to the hospital. I was so pissed off that he wanted me to wait when I was in so much pain, that I hobbled to my car and drove myself.
output: You drove yourself to the hospital with a crushed foot?

instruction: I had a hard time driving, and it was really hard hopping from the parking lot to the emergency room entrance. Emergency is a real zoo. The television show "ER" doesn't do it justice. And it didn't help matters that I was fuming mad. I was so pissed off at Charlotte for squashing my foot and at Rob for being such an ineffectual wimp.
output: Hmm. What kind of painkillers have you been taking?

instruction: Tylenol with codeine. It really helps with the pain.
output: Good. Are you able to work?

instruction: I took a day off so I could get used to the crutches. It's a little hard getting to and from work. But most of the time when I'm at SII, I'm sitting, so it doesn't matter much.
output: I see. How are things at work?

instruction: Everyone's been very solicitous. It's really annoying. Godzilla--that terminally perky, self-appointed doyenne of office hospitality--gave me a get-well card signed by everyone and another box of candy. I wonder if she's fattening me up for the slaughter.
output: It could have been meant as a friendly gesture.

instruction: I hate happy, positive people. Every time she gives me one of her Novocaine smiles, I want to kick her teeth in. I just want to put her head on a pike.
output: Hmm.

instruction: It's odd. The people at work are going out of their way to be nice to me, offering to get me lunch and carry my things. And I've always thought they didn't like me. When Godzilla gave me another box of candy--the same kind that she gave me in the hospital--it led me to think that she might regard chocolate as some sort of magical elixir. Well, either that, or she bought a large quantity of See's 1-pound Nuts-and-Chews boxes at a discount. Rob, on the other hand, has been a real...well, he's not bending over backwards to help me out around the house. And I think he should, because it was partially his fault or rather his wife's fault. Maybe it's not reasonable to hold him accountable for what his wife does.
output: Have you tried talking to Rob about this?

instruction: No. I'd much rather avoid him. He was getting on my nerves anyway.
output: I see.

instruction: Do you know if this is a National Cripples Month or something?
output: The politically correct term is "disabled." No, I don't think so.

instruction: I've been hearing a lot about the Americans with Disabilities Act and the rights of the disabled lately. There was a big discussion on KQED-FM's morning show, "Talk of the Nation." It went on forever! I got so sick of listening to them whine.
output: Hmm.

instruction: Disabled activists are really irritating. It's overkill to expect society to make so many concessions to a problem that affects such a small minority. And do you know what's ironic? With my situation--having to struggle with these crutches up and down the stairs, in and out of bathrooms--I should be sympathetic to their cause, right? Because for the next couple of weeks, I'm disabled, too.
output: Why do you suppose you aren't more sympathetic to the needs of the disabled?

instruction: Because they're so fucking arrogant and demanding, that's why. Look at all the handicapped parking spaces you see. How many people actually use them? Half the time, they're empty--yet another example of political correctness gone amok. I can't use the handicapped spaces, not even with my leg in a cast and with these crutches, because I don't have one of those blue handicapped parking permits. It's unfair that a person couldn't get a "temporary disability" clearance or something, because of an injury.
output: You can.  You should ask your general practitioner to write you a request for temporary disabled parking card.

instruction: Really? Well, I've heard other complaints that the ADA goes too far. Did you know that people who are mentally ill qualify as disabled under the ADA?
output: Yes.

instruction: Do I qualify? I'm a real basket case. I have the scars to prove it.
output: You seem to be managing well.

instruction: I wouldn't mind being labeled a sickie if I could sit at home in front of the television all day and collect a government check.
output: Don't be so quick to judge. Being dependent on SSI is hardly easy or fun. For many, it means having to get by on very little. It's difficult to subsist on a small income in a city like San Francisco.

instruction: Well, I have to admit that's true. Godzilla's disabled.
output: Godzilla?

instruction: Yeah. She has every one of those bullshit disease-of-the-week syndromes: chronic fatigue syndrome, post-traumatic-stress disorder, hypoglycemia...you name it. What a steaming crock. Her most obvious problem is her weight. She isn't even on crutches, and she gets one of those blue handicapped parking thingies. She could obviously use the exercise, but she gets the best parking spaces and hardly has to walk at all.
output: Again, Sharon, don't jump to conclusions. How much do you really know about any of the conditions you just mentioned?

instruction: Sitting next to her, I hear plenty. If she's really in such bad shape, how come she manages to come to work every day?
output: Some people choose to work in spite of serious, even painful, physical disabilities. Think of it as a triumph over adversity.

instruction: I prefer to think of it as fishing for sympathy.
output: I've treated patients with some of the disorders you've just mentioned. It's a common misperception that a person suffering from Chronic Fatigue Syndrome is malingering, but I can tell you from personal experience that isn't true.  It's a heartbreaking condition that robs these people of the chance for a normal life.

instruction: Well, most of the problems Godzilla described are so vague: muscle aches, poor coordination, insomnia, feeling tired all the time. Half the planet has those symptoms.
output: What your co-worker experiences might be more severe than you realize. I can say with authority that hypoglycemia, Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder, and Chronic Fatigue Syndrome do exist and they all can be severely debilitating.

instruction: I guess I don't sound very compassionate. But I'm not saying, "Kill all the cripples," like Doctor Kervorkian. Did you know he actually said that some quadriplegics would be better off dead?
output: Doctor Kervorkian has never been known for either his political correctness or his bedside manner. I suggest you explore the real reason why a discussion of the Americans with Disabilities Act provokes so much animosity in you.

instruction: It's mostly envy. I'm not screwed up enough to be considered "disabled." But I think I'm right on the cusp. I'd be less hostile if I could only get one of those blue handicapped parking thingies.
output: Ask your doctor. But bear in mind that your injury is only temporary. There are many disabled people who live with permanent conditions that are much more severe.

instruction: Yeah, well...
output: Did you return to the recovery group?

instruction: Yes, but it's for the last time. I don't want to go back.
output: Why not?

instruction: Rational Recovery doesn't push meetings the way AA does.
output: As I said earlier, it's important to have support in the early stages of recovery, particularly when you've used highly addictive substances like methamphetamine and heroin.

instruction: I'm not comfortable there. And it's hard for me to schlepp around on these crutches.
output: I think it would be a good idea for you to continue with the group for at least another month. It will give you a good foundation.
