All this domesticity is enough to drive anyone mad.
output: I'm sure Rob appreciates what you do.

instruction: No, he doesn't. He's been nagging me to go back to work. Rob was even pressuring me to go back to SII when I was still in the wheelchair--it was something about having too much time on my hands. Can you believe that?
output: Don't you feel ready to go back to work?

instruction: I'm still in a cast, aren't I?
output: Yes, but you've been upgraded, so to speak, to a temporary cast, and you seem to be a lot more mobile now. You're only using one crutch these days. That's a marked improvement from the wheelchair.

instruction: It's difficult for me to walk, and I tire easily, especially with all the running around I do for Rob. It pisses me off that he has the gall to tell me to get back to work.

instruction: Because I've been busting my ass waiting on him, and he didn't do a fucking thing for me when I was injured. I had to drive myself to the hospital with a broken foot. output: Rob's condition doesn't sound minor...

instruction: Why do you always take his side?
output: I'm not taking sides, Sharon. I realize you've had major injuries over the past few months, but Rob is also grappling with serious health issues. And he's much older than you are, and these conditions are more debilitating for an older person. I also understand that caring for a sick person can be unpleasant--they can be demanding and irritable. So please keep this in mind. I think this is a good time for you to use the relaxation techniques we've discussed.

instruction: I have been using them.
output: You have?

instruction: Okay, maybe not as often as I should, but I try to do it once a week.
output: I'd like you to do them at least once a day, Sharon.

instruction: Okay, okay.
output: Have you heard from Lila?

instruction: Lila who?
output: Come on, Sharon.

instruction: Fuck her. I hope I never see that little cunt again.

output: Have you tried delegating your responsibilities to the other students?

instruction: No one wants to do any work. Beavis and Butthead can barely write their own names. I can't ask Lila. output: Sharon, you didn't even give this woman a chance. She may dress in a manner you find unappealing, but that has no bearing on her ability to assist you.

instruction: She makes me want to hurl. I don't want to have to look at that old Camel Toe, she's just too repulsive.
output: Hmm.

instruction: I know what you're thinking--I have painfully bad hair, and yet I have the gall to criticize someone else's appearance.

instruction: The always perceptive, ever compassionate, and politically correct Doctor Balis. You would never scream at me to pull my head out of my ass and get my shit together, no matter how much you might want to.

instruction: You'd get better results with a thick-headed numskull like me if you acted more like a drill sergeant.

instruction: Yes, just look what great strides you've made with me so far.

instruction: It's a scam, that's what it is. You guys are nothing but third-rate con-artists, even worse than television evangelists and palm readers.

instruction: You're the only constant in my life. You're also the only man in my life who isn't too terribly physically repelling, at least not yet.
output: Thanks for the compliment.

instruction: Sure. I'll see you next week, okay?
output: Goodbye, Sharon.

instruction: Yeah, I went to the doctor last Wednesday. It feels weird walking without it. I'm all wobbly, like I'm drunk or something.

instruction: It's weird having short hair. It doesn't hang in my face anymore, and I can't hide behind it.

instruction: There are other benefits, too. Like weight loss, for instance. My pants actually fit now.

instruction: But I like that lightheaded feeling I get when I chug half a bottle of Ny-Quil or Robitussin and don't eat all day.

instruction: I don't know. Time is so amorphous, it swirls and morphs like the colored globs in a lava lamp...

instruction: You know what else is great about being sick?

instruction: Snot and phlegm. I've been very productive lately. It gives me a great sense of accomplishment when I can generate a lot of mucous. When I look into a tissue after I've blown my nose and see green globules, clinging together in a viscous syrup--like the globs in a lava lamp--I feel like I've done something worthwhile.

instruction: Rob said no, of course. Even in his weakened state, he knows what hell that would be.
output: Hmm.

instruction: Oh, but you do. Especially if you're a woman: "No, honey, your penis is actually above average in size, according to statistics. That's a very nice bookshelf you've built. You're not fat at all, I think it's cute the way your stomach hangs halfway down your thigh."

instruction: I lack the requisite relationship skills. I'm doomed to be a ho.

output: Sharon, you yourself said that you find it difficult to approach people. Wouldn't you like to overcome that?

instruction: It's hopeless. I can't even get through a sentence without saying "uh." You're never going to make an orator out of me.

instruction: Your powers of perception never fail to astound me.

instruction: I care more about him than that bloodsucking breed-sow. It makes me sick, the way she keeps a vigil at his bedside. I saw her at the hospital, she was actually praying! I can't stand her amateur theatrics--all that sobbing and sniveling. I bet it makes Rob even sicker having to listen to her.

instruction: No, no one will give me any information. They won't even let me talk to him on the phone. And when I got home from the hospital, Charlotte was there and told me to leave. I told her to go fuck herself. The next day, when I came home from work, all the locks were changed.

instruction: I took a rock from the yard and broke a window in the kitchen. She saw me as I crawled in and threatened to call the police. I must have looked deranged, because she did what I wanted. I told her to sit her fat ass down so I could get a few things, then I left.

instruction: In my car. I parked it along Fulton Street, next to the park. A lot of car-dwellers hang out there. I wish I bought a Buick instead of an econo-box. My back hurts from being so cramped.

instruction: If there were, do you think I'd be living in my car?

I can't do that--I have to work. I'm almost all out of money now. I'm hoping with my next check from SII, I'll be able to get a cheap apartment or maybe a room at a residential hotel. But I'll have to wait another week for that, though.
output: It must be difficult to report to work...

instruction: Your brilliance knows no bounds, Doctor Balis. Yeah, it's a pain in the ass. The hardest part is trying to be presentable. I didn't bring that many work clothes, and it's difficult to go to the laundry more than a few times a week. One of the assholes in marketing--this big hairy wop--made a comment about my fashion sense...or lack thereof. I hate the way people look at me downtown. Everyone else looks so perfect in their suits and ironed shirts. But no matter what I do, I can't stay clean, and all my clothes get wrinkled.

instruction: I know I stink, Doctor, you don't have to rub my face in it.

instruction: I haven't taken a real shower in a while. I thought about using the ones at Ocean Beach, but the fog comes in, and it's freezing cold by the time I get off work. It's hard to keep warm. I've been using those public pay-toilets instead--the ones in the green kiosks that cost a quarter. I get twenty minutes for every quarter, that's almost enough time to clean myself up. It's hard to wash your hair in those little sinks, though. It's a good thing I cut my hair. I heard those public toilets self-clean. Maybe I should stay in there past the 20-minute limit and get myself hosed down along with the bathroom floor.
output: I wouldn't advise that, Sharon. You might be sprayed with industrial-strength cleaning solvents.

I should give Doctor Kervorkian a call, we can haggle over who gets the patent. I wonder if he's allowed to get incoming phone calls in jail.

output: I need you to be honest with me, Sharon. If you're thinking of hurting yourself, I can arrange to have you hospitalized. At least, that would give you time to recover from your cold, and you'll have a warm bed to sleep in.
